title: requireEnsure runtime missing (__webpack_require__.e is not a function) when an entrypoint has a dynamic AND regular import of a module which is also dynamically imported by a second entrypoint.
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template because we'll close your issue -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->

# Bug report

<!-- Please ask questions on StackOverflow or the webpack Gitter. -->
<!-- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/ask?tags=webpack -->
<!-- https://gitter.im/webpack/webpack -->
<!-- Issues which contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->

**What is the current behavior?**
I have 2 entry points / bundles. Let's call them `A` and `B` they have some modules in common but are loaded on separate pages for example mobile/regular site or internal website / public facing website. therefor it makes more sense to have two dedicated bundles and no common chunk.
Bundle `A` has a dependency on Module `M` in form of a dynamic import i.e. `import("./M")` Bundle B has the same file with a dynamic import but also some regular imports of module M in other files i.e. `import M from "./M"`
when bundling A and B (config `splitChunks -> false` and default `optimization.runtimeChunk: false`). the B bundle has the `__webpack_require__.e(/*! import() | M */ "M")` code to request loading the M chunk. but misses the requireEnsure function (i.e. `__webpack_require__.e = function requireEnsure(chunkId) {`) in its runtime which is only present in the A bundle. And would result to a `__webpack_require__.e is not a function` runtime exception.
When removing the entry point for A from the webpack config, then instead of the requireEnsure call there is a Promise.resolve with the module M which was loaded for the reqular imports.
when removing the regular imports of the Module M from the B then the `requireEnsure` function definition is present in both bundles.
There is a workaround to use `optimization.runtimeChunk: "single"` and load the generated runtime with the requireEnsure part for both bundles. but i would prefer one js file to be generated and needed to be loaded.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce.**


<!-- A great way to do this is to provide your configuration via a GitHub repository -->
<!-- The most helpful is a minimal reproduction with instructions on how to reproduce -->
<!-- Repositories with too many files or large `webpack.config.js` files are not suitable -->
<!-- Please only add small code snippets directly into this issue -->
<!-- https://gist.github.com is a good place for longer code snippets -->
<!-- If your issue is caused by a plugin or loader, please create an issue on the loader/plugin repository instead -->
A CodeSandbox with minimal setup to reproduce this issue and the results are provided under:
https://codesandbox.io/s/llplqpml2q
**What is the expected behavior?**
The B bundle should have Promise.resolve and reference to the already loaded Module M, even if another entrypoint is defined in the webpack config.

<!-- "It should work" is not a helpful explanation -->
<!-- Explain exactly how it should behave -->

**Other relevant information:**
webpack version:  4.20.2
Node.js version: v8.4.0
Operating System:  windows 10
Additional tools: `
    "@babel/core": "7.1.0",
    "@babel/plugin-syntax-dynamic-import": "7.0.0",
    "@babel/preset-env": "7.1.0",
    "babel-loader": "8.0.3",`
